beforeWeGetStarted.p1: Welcome to this page! From here, you will learn CKB ahead of everyone else.
beforeWeGetStarted.p2: In this tutorial, you will learn the basics of CKB, so that you can develop an application on CKB or simply understand them for curiosity's sake.
beforeWeGetStarted.p3: This tutorial is a complete walk-through that allows you to accomplish the following tasks by yourself:

ul1.l1: Build and send the simplest transfer transaction.
ul1.l2: Build and send the simplest multi-signature transaction.
ul1.l3: Build and deploy the simplest smart contract.
ul1.l4: Build and deploy an upgradable smart contract.

beforeWeGetStarted.p4: To figure it all out, there is:

ul2.l1: no need for any local downloads.
ul2.l2: no need to run any software.
ul2.l3: no need even to write one single line of code!

beforeWeGetStarted.p5: On this page you can interact directly with the cloud-based test chain in a manual, remote manner.
beforeWeGetStarted.p6: All you need to have is the patience for reading further down and the curiosity for CKB.

theoreticalKnowledgeMinimized.title: Step 1 Theoretical Knowledge Minimized
theoreticalKnowledgeMinimized.q1: There are no Bitcoins in the world, only UTXOs.
theoreticalKnowledgeMinimized.q2: There are no CKBs in the world, only cells.

unravelCKB.title: What is CKB?
unravelCKB.p1: To understand CKB, we must leave behind all the complex concepts and capture the very essence: it's all about cells and the transformation of cells.
unravelCKB.p2: Cell is the basic unit of CKB, similar to a cell in the human body. Each cell constitutes the general state of the entire CKB blockchain. When we initiate a transaction on the blockchain, thus making a state change, in the end, for CKB, it is nothing more than spending some cells while creating some new ones, no matter how complicated the transaction and the state change are. This process is the same as the Bitcoin UTXO.
unravelCKB.p3: Unspent cells are live cells; spent cells are dead cells. So, a CKB chain keeps on spending and creating cells through transactions, like the renewal and division of cells throughout the body.
unravelCKB.p4: Unlike UTXO, a cell can store any type of data. Each cell has a field called data, where you can put an unformatted string. The string can be in whatever format you want, as long as you can interpret it.
unravelCKB.p5: For example, the string can be a hash, a text, a date, or even a piece of binary code that can be referenced by other cells and run on-chain through the CKB virtual machine, CKB-VM.
unravelCKB.p6: As simple as that, this is the so-called smart contract on CKB.

howToOwnACell.title: How to own a cell?
howToOwnACell.p1: Cells are obtained by the verification of the global consensus on the chain. Owning cells entails costs, since their storage space is limited.
howToOwnACell.p2: This leads us to the function of CKB's native tokens.
howToOwnACell.p3: Imagine a cell as a small box that can carry objects. The box itself is created by tokens. A box's size is determined by how many tokens you have.
howToOwnACell.p4: A box (cell) can also be divided into multiple boxes, as long as the total space of the boxes is equal to the number of tokens you have.
howToOwnACell.p6: In Nervos CKB, 1 CKB is equal to 1 byte of storage space.
howToOwnACell.p7: For example, if you have 100 CKBs, you will have 100 bytes of on-chain space, so you can create a box with 100 bytes of space. You can divide that 100 bytes into as many boxes as you like.
howToOwnACell.p8: The box can store data. The data size must be smaller than the space of the box, because the box includes other components which also occupy some space.
howToOwnACell.p9: For instance, one Chinese character accounts for 2 bytes (GBK encoding). If you have 100 CKBs in a cell, you can probably save less than 50 Chinese characters in it.
howToOwnACell.p10: In the case of Dream of the Red Chamber, this novel is approximately 780,000 words in total, so if you want to upload the whole chunk on-chain, you'll need approximately 1.56 million native CKB tokens.
howToOwnACell.p11: As you can see, on-chain storage is a precious asset.
howToOwnACell.p12: CKB stores consensus data on-chain, enabling everyone to upload data valuable and necessary to consensus. It is comparable to a knowledge base owned by all of humanity.
howToOwnACell.p13: This is how CKB got its name (Common Knowledge Base).
howToOwnACell.p14: The entire cell data structure looks like this:
howToOwnACell.p15: The four fields are defined as follows:

ul1.l1: capacity: the space size of the cell, i.e. the number of native tokens represented by this cell, usually expressed in hexadecimal. The basic unit for capacity is shannon, 1 CKB equals 10**8 shannon.
ul1.l2: lock: a script, which is essentially the equivalent of a lock. We'll show you more details later.
ul1.l3: type: a script, same as the lock but for a different purpose.
ul1.l4: data: an unformatted string where any type of data can be stored.

howToOwnACell.p16: More detailed descriptions of data structures can be found here:
howToOwnACell.p17: NoteÔºöA cell's total size for all four fields above must be less than or equal to the capacity of the cell.
howToOwnACell.p19: To better understand, let's look at the following example.
howToOwnACell.p20: Type in something as the cell data to see the real-time changes in the length of the cell. Click on the cell to view the cell content and the actual length of each field.
howToOwnACell.p21: The capacity of the cell is set as 0x1dcd65000, which is 80 bytes in size. If the change in data causes the actual occupancy to grow beyond the value of capacity, the cell will be considered invalid.

howToKnowCellIsYours.title: How to tell that you own a cell?
howToKnowCellIsYours.p1: The only way you can possess cells is by owning native tokens, so how do we know which one you own?
howToKnowCellIsYours.p2: Do you remember the lock and type scripts we mentioned above?
howToKnowCellIsYours.p3: If the cell is a box, the lock and type scripts are the two locks on the box.
howToKnowCellIsYours.p4: The lock script is the default lock, and the type script is an optional lock.
howToKnowCellIsYours.p5: In essence, the scripts are a piece of code and parameters. When we try to consume a cell, the scripts will automatically run and enter the parameters and proof we submit (such as the signature) to determine if the locks of the cell can be unlocked. Once unlocked, it proves that we own and control the cell.
howToKnowCellIsYours.p6: The script structure looks like this:
howToKnowCellIsYours.p7: In these three fields, hash_type is reserved for later, the other two are:

ul1.l1: the hash of a certain piece of code
ul1.l2: the arguments that will be transferred to the code

howToKnowCellIsYours.p8: More data structure details can be found here:
howToKnowCellIsYours.p9: The code_hash and args jointly constitute a full lock: we locate the code to be executed by using the code_hash field and then send the argument args to this code. The code will then be executed by the CKB virtual machine CKB-VM (Additional args may be read during the process, such as the proof attached to the transaction). If executed successfully, a ‚Äú0‚Äù will be returned indicating that the lock can be opened successfully; if not, other values will be returned indicating that the unlocking failed.
howToKnowCellIsYours.p10: With this principle, CKB identifies the owner of a cell, i.e. who can open the lock attached to the cell. The same principle applies to Bitcoin.
howToKnowCellIsYours.p11: We could introduce an asymmetric encryption algorithm via code_hash and place our own public key on the args as an argument. When we need to spend the cell, to initiate a transaction, we could use the private key to sign the transaction so that the cryptographic algorithm could input the public key and signature to figure out whether the corresponding private key initiated the transaction, thus identifying whether it was the real cell owner.
howToKnowCellIsYours.p12: If, on the other hand, you create a cell with a lock that can be unlocked by anyone, meaning anyone can spend the cell, that is spending your money! This is dangerous. Locks are vital to the cell.

takeBreak1.p1: Well, you have managed to read this far, let's recap what we have learned up to now:

ul1.l1: CKB is essentially a chain of cells that are constantly being created and destroyed.
ul1.l2: A cell is a box that can be used to store all types of data.
ul1.l3: To own a cell, you need tokens. The number of tokens equals the size of the cell. 1 CKB = 1 Byte.
ul1.l4: The size of the entire cell cannot exceed the value of the capacity field.
ul1.l5: To protect your cell, you must put a lock on the cell that only you can open.

takeBreak1.p2: It seems that we've got a pretty good grasp of how CKB works. Great! Trust me, you've got most of it figured out. Now, let's get into a bit more detail.

whereIsTheActualCode.title: Where is the code actually located?
whereIsTheActualCode.p1: We have learned that the lock and type fields of the cell are used to lock the box and to guarantee its ownership and control.
whereIsTheActualCode.p2: Lock is a script structure that looks like this:
whereIsTheActualCode.p3: You may notice that the code_hash is not the actual code but a hash of the code, equivalent to an index of the code. This index allows us to retrieve the code. So, where is the code anyway?
whereIsTheActualCode.p4: The answer is simple: code is in another cell!
whereIsTheActualCode.p5: We know that the data field of the cell can contain arbitrary data, so we can put the real code in the data field of another cell and implement this cell as a dependency to a transaction. This dependency cell is called ‚Äúdep cell‚Äù.
whereIsTheActualCode.p6: When unlocking a cell, we simply import the dep cell, and CKB will match the hash of the data in the dep cell with code_hash to find the corresponding code.
whereIsTheActualCode.p7: So why not just put in the real code, but use this indexing approach?
whereIsTheActualCode.p8: One of the major advantages of this design is that if everyone needs the same type of lock, the lock code will be identical, the code_hash value will be identical, too. Then it is just a matter of introducing the same dep cell rather than deploying the same code all over again for each case.
whereIsTheActualCode.p10: CKB has an important built-in smart contract called SECP256K1_BLAKE160. It is the default lock used by each cell in the lock field in regular transfer transactions. This lock means the SECP256K1 encryption algorithm protects the ownership of each cell.
whereIsTheActualCode.p11: To achieve this, CKB created several cells in the genesis block and then put the specific code of the SECP256K1 encryption algorithm into the data field of these cells. During the transaction, these cells are introduced as dep cells. Then we fill in the code_hash with the hash of the dep cell's data field while putting our public key hash in the args field, so the lock can determine whether the signature attached to a transfer transaction is authentic and valid.
whereIsTheActualCode.p12: But at this point, another question may come to your mind.

whatIfCodeIsLost.title: What if the lock code is lost?
whatIfCodeIsLost.p1: The code of lock is kept in another cell. What if someone destroys that cell? When this cell is spent, the dep cell becomes dead, and the code of lock will be gone. Does this mean that the cell that uses this lock can no longer unlock it?
whatIfCodeIsLost.p2: Theoretically, this is true. Technically, the cell that contains the code of the lock should last as long as the chain does, and no one can access this cell. So, if you look it up, you can see that the dep cells that all the built-in lock scripts of CKB have been built on are inherently inaccessible by anyone. Because we have set the value 0x0000... in the lock field of each dep cell (i.e. the lock of the cell itself where to put the lock code), which means that no one will ever be able to unlock these cells again, and the code will always be there:
whatIfCodeIsLost.p3: We can still unlock our own cell if the dep cell was destroyed, because you can just redeploy the same lock code to a new cell and then bring in the new cell as a dep cell so that you can retrieve the lock code. Because the code remains identical, the hash of the code stays the same, and the value of code_hash also remains the same. This is the additional flexibility of CKB.
whatIfCodeIsLost.p4: These examples of locks that we've talked about are the locks in the lock field of the cell.
whatIfCodeIsLost.p5: In addition to the default lock, lock script, a cell can also have an optional lock, type script. These two locks are fundamentally the same, but they are given different names because of their different uses.
whatIfCodeIsLost.p6: The lock script is usually used to protect the ownership of the box, while the type script is used to ensure that the cell follows certain data transformation rules during the transaction.
whatIfCodeIsLost.p7: To understand this, we must start by understanding what a transaction in CKB is all about.
whatIfCodeIsLost.p8: Constructing a transaction is to destroy some cells and create some more.
whatIfCodeIsLost.p9: The essence of a transaction in CKB, excluding the less important details, is as followsÔºö
whatIfCodeIsLost.p10: Where the essence of input and output is still about some cellsÔºö
whatIfCodeIsLost.p11: The cells in the input must all be live cells. The input cells will be spent and become dead cells after a transaction is committed. The newly created output cells will become new live cells.
whatIfCodeIsLost.p12: The most important rule you need to remember about CKB transactions is that all output cells, i.e. the newly created boxes, must take up less space than input cells.
whatIfCodeIsLost.p13: It's because the extra space between input and output is the fee that the miner earns. Miners are motivated by transaction fees.
whatIfCodeIsLost.p14: In practice, we do not put the full cell in the input for storage optimization purposes; instead, we just put the cell's index and use the index to find the cell used as input.
whatIfCodeIsLost.p15: This index structure is called OutPoint, which allows you to find a particular cell.

roleOfTypeLock.title: Role of the type script
roleOfTypeLock.p1: As cells are transformed from inputs to outputs in a transaction, certain user-defined rules can guide the transformation process.
roleOfTypeLock.p2: For example, I want a cell to produce only one new cell at a time in a transaction, I can make such a rule into a lock on the box.
roleOfTypeLock.p3: Another example, I would like a cell to never show the word ‚Äúcarrot‚Äù in its data field during a transaction, I could create a lock with such a rule, which would be added as a type lock to the box.
roleOfTypeLock.p4: This is the distinction between the type script and the lock script. The former protects the ownership of the box and the latter secures the data transformation rules. The lock lock is the gatekeeper, while the type lock is the guardian.
roleOfTypeLock.p5: This variance in use comes down to the difference in the design of the two locks in terms of their execution mechanism which can be specified as follows:

ul1.l1: Lock script: In a transaction, the lock scripts of all inputs will be executed once.
ul1.l2: Type script: In a transaction, the type scripts of all inputs and outputs will be executed once.

roleOfTypeLock.p6: Due to the variations in execution mechanisms, derived usage also varies. You are free to have your own opinions on this, but essentially these are the recommended official usages.

takeABreak2.p1: Congratulations! Now you are prepared for the tutorial!
takeABreak2.p2: Let's review all the concepts we have learned:

ul1.l1: CKB is essentially a chain of cells which are being created and destroyed over and over again.
ul1.l2: A cell is a box that can be used to store any type of data.
ul1.l3: To own a cell, you need tokens. The amount of tokens equals the size of the cell. 1 CKB = 1 Byte.
ul1.l4: The size of the entire cell cannot exceed the value of the capacity field.
ul1.l5: To protect your cell, you must put a lock on the cell that only your key can unlock.
ul1.l6: The lock is essentially a piece of runnable code and some arguments. Through entering args and some signatures or proofs provided by the user, the code runs to check if the lock can be opened.
ul1.l7: The return value of 0 means that the lock was unlocked successfully, while any other value means the unlock attempt failed.
ul1.l8: Using the code_hash of the cell, the lock's code can be retrieved. This code is stored in the data field of a dep cell.
ul1.l9: Each cell can carry two locks, one is called lock script (default) and the other, type script (optional).
ul1.l10: In one transaction, the lock scripts of all inputs will be executed once.
ul1.l11: In one transaction, the type scripts of both inputs and outputs will be executed once.
ul1.l12: The differences in the execution mechanism result in different uses for the two locks.
ul1.l13: Lock scripts are often used to protect the ownership of the box.
ul1.l14: Type scripts are usually used to ensure that the box's data conversion rules are followed.
ul1.l15: Constructing a transaction is fundamentally about destroying some cells and creating some new ones.

takeABreak2.p3: That's right, with the above theoretical knowledge, you're ready to hit the road.
takeABreak2.p4: Afterward, we'll have a hands-on experience with CKB!

getYourHandDirty.title: Step 2. Practice
getYourHandDirty.p1: Better understand the previous theory by getting some hands-on experience of CKB blockchain.

studyAChain.title: Study a Chain
studyAChain.p1: We are running a test chain over the cloud and have pre-generated account addresses for this tutorial.
studyAChain.p2: Click on the buttons below and check out the latest blocks.
studyAChain.p4: By hovering over the wallets you can open them.
studyAChain.p5: Each wallet carries four messages, meant as follows:

ul1.l1: mainnet: indicates the mainnet address of the wallet
ul1.l2: testnet: indicates the testnet address of the wallet. In this tutorial, we only use the testnet addresses
ul1.l3: lock_arg: indicates the first 20 bits of the wallet's corresponding public key hash. Think of it simply as a fingerprint of the public key.
ul1.l4: private_key: the private key of the wallet. You should not expose it as what I did.

studyAChain.p6: In this tutorial, these wallets will be used for sending transactions, deploying contracts, and other purposes.
studyAChain.p7: To view the associated cells and transactions, select any of the wallets listed below.
studyAChain.p8: Click on any cell or transaction to view the details in JSON format.
studyAChain.p9: The amount of the CKBs (native tokens) a wallet has represents the capacity of all the live cells that the wallet can unlock, i. e. the total on-chain storage space the wallet occupies.
studyAChain.p10: Now, wallet 1 serves as the default miner address on this test chain.
studyAChain.p11: In other words, wallet 1 will continuously receive rewards generated by mining. As a result, wallet 1 has the most live cells, while wallets 2 and 3 have very few or no live cells.
studyAChain.p12: Currently, there is only one miner on the test chain.
studyAChain.p13: It is also important to know the configuration information of this test chain.
studyAChain.p15: indicates that this chain is the test chain rather than the mainnet.
studyAChain.p16: represent the built-in smart contracts, i.e. some of the system's built-in locks that type and lock can use.
studyAChain.p17: Several built-in smart contracts will be pre-deployed in each CKB chain's genesis block. The following are three of the built-in smart contracts.

ul2.l1: SECP256K1_BLAKE160: the system's default smart contract for the lock script of cells, used to protect the ownership of the cells.
ul2.l2: SECP256K1_BLAKE160_MULTISIG: the multi-signature version of SECP256K1_BLAKE160.
ul2.l3: DAO: NervosDAO contract. Feel free to ignore it if you don't understand.

studyAChain.p18: Well, that's all the information we need to know.
studyAChain.p19: Now we'll build our first transaction and send it!

cellConcept.p1: In the CKB universe, countless cells are floating around.
cellConcept.p2: Cells store data that jointly form the general state of the chain.

outPoint.txHashText: Hash value of the affiliated transaction(to which transaction it belongs)

class1.title: Send a Transaction
class1.p1: In this section, we will have a hands-on lesson on how to complete a basic transfer transaction.
class1.p2: A quick refresher before we start:
class1.p3: A CKB transaction is nothing more than spending some existing live cells and creating some new ones.
class1.p4: Because CKB is designed as ‚Äúoff-chain computing, on-chain verifying‚Äù, we can complete a transfer operation by constructing transactions manually.
class1.p5: As long as we draw up the content of the transaction in advance (i.e., which cells will be spent and which new cells will be created), then we sign the transaction with the corresponding private key. Once the transaction is submitted to the chain, as long as it passes the verification and is signed in a validated manner, this transaction is completed and will be packaged.
class1.p6: What does such a manual construction of a transaction mean?
class1.p7: In the CKB system, we compose the layer 2 network.
class1.p8: Imagine you have a friend who lives in an Amazon jungle isolated from everything but an offline computer.
class1.p9: When he returned from hunting one afternoon, he remembered he owed you some money. So he turned on the computer and attempted to transfer 10,000 CKBs to you to settle his debt.
class1.p10: Although he was unable to access the internet, he wrote down the transaction details on paper, entered his private key into the computer, calculated the appropriate signature, and attached his signature.
class1.p11: When a courier visited half a month later, he asked to send the paper to China by mail. That letter finally reached you half a month after it was sent.
class1.p12: The message on the mail did specify the transaction of 10,000 CKBs to you. Then you decided to submit the transaction to the CKB mainnet.
class1.p13: After the mainnet validated the attached signature, the transaction was complete and you now have 10,000 more CKBs in your account. The debt was settled.
class1.p14: Despite low throughput, only 1 transaction per month, you and your Amazon jungle buddy have created a layer2 network containing 2 nodes.
class1.p15: CKB offers tools for automatically building transactions, transferring contracts, etc. Nevertheless, we will continue with this old-school method to implement a regular transfer transaction.
class1.p16: By using manually assembled transactions, you will gain a deeper understanding of how CKB cells work.
class1.p17: We will use the JSON format to do this.

transactionInput.title: Transaction Input
transactionInput.p1: The following are the 4 live cells from wallet 1. Simply drag the cells into the box below and you will see the automatically generated inputs.
transactionInput.p2: The cell in inputs appears in previous_output which is imported as an outpoint composed of tx_hash and index, akin to an index, or a pointer to the cell, by which we can locate the cell to be spent.
transactionInput.p3: The since field in the inputs controls the time. Don't worry about it for now.
transactionInput.p4: Besides inputs, there is a field called cell_deps that indicates the dependency cells a transaction needs to rely on. This field appears as an index result in out_point.
transactionInput.p6: In a regular transfer transaction, the lock script requires a fixed encryption algorithm, SECP256K1_BLAKE160, a built-in smart contract. The encryption algorithm code is kept in a cell and must be referenced in cell_deps, so that CKB-VM knows where to import it for calculation.
transactionInput.p7: The arguments in cell_deps can easily be found by checking the configuration information demonstrated in the test chain above.

transactionOutput.title: Transaction Output
transactionOutput.p1: The next step is to use another tool to see how the output is generated and how the entire transaction looks.
transactionOutput.p2: Again, drag the cell from wallet 1 to INPUT.
transactionOutput.p3: A new cell of an identical size will be automatically generated in OUTPUT.
transactionOutput.p4: Click the ‚öô button in OUTPUT to reassign the newly generated cells. This includes specifying how many cells to generate, the size and the unlock address of each cell, and so on.
transactionOutput.p5: The output must have less capacity than the input, and the gap is the fee to reward miners.
transactionOutput.p6: To view the transaction JSON, click Generate Transaction once you've set it up.
transactionOutput.p7: The outputs of the transaction have all the information about the newly generated cell, including its capacity, lock script, etc.
transactionOutput.p8: Cells in the outputs do not specify data information; the data is located in the outputs_data field, which corresponds to the cells in the outputs accordingly. Again, this is designed for performance optimization.
transactionOutput.p9: Complete transactions also contain fields such as version and header_deps. The version field indicates the version, which is currently set to 0x0, while the header_deps field is null.

signTheTransaction.title: Sign a Transaction
signTheTransaction.p1: Once a transaction has been assembled, it must be signed by the corresponding private key. The private key indicates that the cells belong to you and you can operate on them.
signTheTransaction.p2: Afterward, the signature will be put into a new field called witnesses, which serves as proof of the transaction.
signTheTransaction.p3: It is now clear how a transaction works. Let's move on to constructing a transfer transaction manually.

buildATransaction.title: Build a Transaction
buildATransaction.p1: Fill in the transaction information in the transaction template below.
buildATransaction.p2: This is an exercise to practice completing a transfer transaction on your own.
buildATransaction.p3: You can use the toolbox on the right side to find the live cells associated with your wallet, to view chain configuration information (so you can fill in cell_deps) and to convert hex to decimal, etc.
buildATransaction.p4: To open the toolbox, click on the Nervos icon. üëâ
buildATransaction.p5: After filling it out, click the Save button.
buildATransaction.p6: You have filled in all the transaction information manually.
buildATransaction.p7: Consequently, we are now able to generate a unique hash for the transaction, i.e., we can generate the tx_hash beforehand.

generateTxHash.title: Generate the Transaction Hash
generateTxHash.p1: To generate the transaction hash, click the button below.
generateTxHash.p2: The transaction used to generate the tx_hash is still a raw transaction. The witnesses fileld needs to be filled in with the signature of the transaction for the raw transaction to become a complete transaction structure.
generateTxHash.p3: You can put any arguments or proofs you need in the witnesses field. As an array, the witnesses field can include multiple proofs. Because we are now building a built-in transfer transaction, the following structure must be placed in the first position of each set of witnesses:
generateTxHash.p4: This structure is called WitnessArgs. Different locks retrieve the required signature from different fields within WitnessArgs. The lock field contains the signature to be verified by the locks of input cells.
generateTxHash.p5: In our case, this is the signature required by the SECP256K1_BLAKE160 algorithm for verification.
generateTxHash.p6: The input_type and output_type fields contain the signatures to be verified by the type locks in inputs and outputs. Feel free to ignore them for now.
generateTxHash.p7: The process of signing is tedious. Here is more information:

generateMessage.title: Generate the Message
generateMessage.p1: To sign the transaction, we must generate a message.

completeSining.title: Sign the Transaction
completeSining.p1: Using the message and the private key of our wallet, we can calculate the signature.

putBackSignature.title: Put the Signature Back into the Transaction
putBackSignature.p1: Enter the generated signature in the following box and click on the button to serialize witnessArgs:
putBackSignature.p2: It is now time to finalize the raw transaction by adding the serialized signature to the witnesses field.

sendTransaction.title: Send the Transaction
sendTransaction.p1: The final step is to send the transaction back on-chain.
sendTransaction.p2: Congratulations on completing the first section of the tutorial!
sendTransaction.p3: Next, we will learn how to send a multi-signature transfer transaction.
